Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives. 

And to #3, yes the booze came from Bethel, the only hub here. The villages all vote to be dry but BET lets it pour in & profits from it.

Comment: Peeing in the park/alley when you think no one is looking is not an offense that requires registration as a sex offender in the State of Colorado. It also does not meet the elements of Public Indecency (which only requires registration after a second conviction within 5 years), which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person.

Also, the juvenile sex offender registry is not made available to the public in the same way as the adult sex offender registry. And first-time juvenile sex offenders are able to petition for de-registration once they have successfully completed their sentence.

Comment: http://www.thefiscaltimes.com/Articles/2011/02/09/10-Big-Corporate-Tax-Breaks
U.S. corporations — like many Americans — exploit every available rule in the tax code to minimize the taxes they pay. The United States has one of the highest corporate tax rates in the world, at 35 percent (not including any state levies), yet the actual amount in corporate taxes that the government collects (“the effective tax rate”) is lower than those of Germany, Canada, Japan and China, among others. The reason is confusingly called “tax expenditures,” a doublespeak term designed to legitimize special interest tax breaks and loopholes. 
Those ‘expenditures’ will cost the U.S. government $628.6 billion over the next five years, according to a 2010 report from the Tax Foundation.  With advice from the Urban Institute’s Eric Toder, one of the country’s foremost authorities on corporate tax policy, we assembled the 10 most costly corporate tax loopholes and who benefits from them.

Comment: I agree with you on the informal schism but short of reconciling this, I think a formal schism would allow people from both camps to practice their faiths more honestly and authentically. However, I don't think a schism will occur under Pope Francis unless it is the conservatives who split. But in essence they can't because the Bishop of Rome is the purported leader of the universal church. Perhaps PF's desire to be called the Bishop of Rome (as opposed to "Pope") was a first step toward hierarchical decentralization, and this would open the door for bishops to guide their respective flocks according to the principles of sensus fidelium. This is all pure speculaltion of course, IMO it is more likely that successive popes will continue to confound matters by insisting that their vision for the church is tantamount to Divine Truth, thereby furthering the RCC down the path of ecclesial irrelevance. Comment: Sessions was forced to recuse him from federal Russia investigations after The Washington Post reported that the former Alabama senator had met twice with the Russian ambassador, even though he testified during his confirmation hearing in January that he “did not have communications with the Russians.” Later, it was revealed that there was a third undisclosed meeting.

On Jan. 17, Sen. Patrick J. Leahy (D-Vt.) asked Sessions in a letter: “Several of the President-Elect’s nominees or senior advisers have Russian ties. Have you been in contact with anyone connected to any part of the Russian government about the 2016 election, either before or after Election Day?”

Sessions replied, “No.” This answer has been proven to be false.

18 U.S. Code 1001 applies to the Leahy letter even if Sessions’s responses to the senator weren’t sworn. This statute prohibits falsifying or hiding information or providing materially false or fraudulent information to the government — even if not under oath.

Comment: As a very new teacher I had a (girl) learner giving me a hard time in class.  Sarah was a buxom lass, just as tall as I.  I didn't realise it at the time, but my right hand was twitching - wanting to strike her.  
She noticed it.  She looked at me levelly and said: "Strike me, Ma'am, and you have lost your job!"   
That broke the tension and we both just let it go.
However, I went home and reflected on it for a long time.  I had been trained never to hit a learner, but I now realised that - somewhere in the back of my mind - I did think that I could hit someone - as a 'last resort'.   I was shocked at me, and I had to accept that shame before I could move forward.  
That long afternoon and evening (and many times since) I had to think of strategies which I could use to get the 'Sarahs' of this world to do what I wanted them to do - and be happy about it!   
This was one of the best confrontations that I ever had. Forty years later, I am grateful to Sarah.

As the Washington Post reports today:
“It's highly unlikely there was a wiretap,” said one former senior intelligence official familiar with surveillance law who spoke candidly on the condition of anonymity. The former official continued: “It seems unthinkable. If that were the case by some chance, that means that a federal judge would have found that there was either probable cause that he [Trump] had committed a crime or was an agent of a foreign power.”

A wiretap cannot be directed at a U.S. facility, the official said, without finding probable cause that the phone lines or Internet addresses were being used by agents of a foreign power — or by someone spying for or acting on behalf of a foreign government. “You can't just go around and tap buildings,” the official said.

Comment: Well, to be fair, forecasting weather in Anchorage is extremely difficult.  Note that in the roughly 40-ish miles as the crow flies from ANC to Whittier the average annual precipitation goes up by roughly 10X.  We are often in a scenario of how much "weather" makes it over the mountains to our side (the lee side) and because you have considerable climatological variation in such a short distance it is very difficult to nail any particular forecast.  They do the best they can with the tools they have.  To be sure, they are actually more correct than it seems and they definitely do a better job than someone without any training.  So give them a break...

Comment: I'm an SEIU represented govt employee. Please don't spread lies or misinformation about us. 

During the recession we had layoffs (I got a layoff notice as did some of my co-workers), and we had to take furlough days and went years with wage freezes. The wage freeze is very costly as it means we're a couple or three steps behind for many, many years until we get topped out on the scale. Even today I'm making less because of the recession because I'd otherwise be 2-3 steps higher on the pay scale. We also agreed to start paying into our health insurance during that time, and we still do. 

I'm not saying we had it worst, but I am getting tired of the lies that public service workers were pigs at the trough during the recession. We took big concessions and didn't strike over it. We agreed to it. To not give us credit for it makes us wonder why we bother in the first place if nothing we do is ever credited.

Comment: You bring up a very good as well as a very complicated point. Local funding of public education, that is to say property taxes supplementing state foundation program allocations, is effective when you have, as is the case of the rest of the US, local control of the public school districts. The problem that our system in Hawaii has sought to address is the issue of funding equity. Schools in districts with high property values and a relatively affluent population receive more funding than schools in low-income low tax districts. You end up with situations like Fairfax County VA where most of the schools are well-funded and quite successful versus some districts in northern MI where schools have been closed and programs curtailed. Funding of public education is complex and is a balancing act among competing needs and societal goals.

Comment: Yes, and I hate them. They make it very difficult to see down the block and determine whether or not a car is coming. They are the same wave lengths as modern bike lights, so we get lost in the glare, and even on the bike paths they are blinding. (Add in the fact that some idiot put them in what should be the clear-zone of the bike path so that they present a substantial additional hazard in the event of a mishap, and I'm really, really not a fan.)

As far as cyclists being especially vulnerable, when all things are considered, being in a car is equally dangerous as being on a bike on a per hour basis, and much more dangerous from the standpoint of traumatic brain injuries. Crashes can kill or maim no matter one's mode, but cyclists have better ability to avoid them than motorists. We all have an interest in safe roads, but for some reason many motorists resist the low-hanging fruit of removing dangerous drivers by increasing patrols.

Comment: As maybe a final kick at it:
.
The Air Ministry picked the Bouton-Paul Defiant, Fairey Battle,  Hampden, and Bristol Blenheim as winners.  The US thought the Brewster Buffalo was a suitable front-line aircraft.
.
By contrast, the Fairey Swordfish, Hawker Hurricane,  Supermarine Spitfire, and DH Mosquito were all initially privately developed.
.
The Vickers Wellington was initially viewed with Air Ministry skepticism, as was the Avro design that eventually became the Lancaster.
.
Parsons built the Turbinia without assistance from the Admiralty.  Only after the unwanted demonstration at Spithead did the Admiralty take interest.
.
Orville and Wilbur Wright never received a penny of government subsidy in developing the Flyer.
.
Bureaucrats know about bureaucratic politics.
.
Entrepreneurs know about innovative products.
.
Governments are not entrepreneurs, nor should they pretend to be.
.
Other than CD Howe, Governments have a terrible history of trying to pick winners in technology.

Comment: It would be great if American also remembered the wives and children of those who came back from war with PTSD and took their pain, anger, loss and bitterness out on their families,  with absolutely no help from the military or government. She and us kids took all the abuse and violence that he brought home in his war-fueled rages.  But where are the Boy Scouts reverently putting lei on HER grave?

Remembering only some of the victims of war,  without considering all the consequences of America's addiction to violence both at home and abroad, does us no good as a civil society.  We need to be finding ways to NEVER have to send good men and women to war ever again,  so that no one has to come home sick and angry after being trained to hurt and kill other human beings.

Comment: Religious priests, like the Benedictines, have been around for centuries [and unlike diocesan priests], they have a shared understanding of wisdom---because of their life-long spiritual formation--daily call to prayer/reflection and a gospel life-style.  We wouldn't even have had a liturgy in the West, if the Benedictines weren't  printing the liturgy out by hand.
Take a look at history in the West during the Dark Ages.  The Western Roman Empire disintegrated in the fifth century. Western Europe faced wave after wave of barbarian invasions--Vandals, Goths, Vikings, the Huns---then the Lombards [in Italy] and the Franks.  While Gregory the Great [d. 604] was able to both control the Lombards and regulate Church life, after he died, the popes were not that strong.

It was the Benedictines at the large monastery in Cluny, France---that helped reform both the church, print out and hand bind books on the liturgy, AND give support to the popes trying to maintain church autonomy.

Comment: I am not sure how this will be implemented.  The main failure of this initiative is that there is not enough detail in what is being proposed. The BC carbon tax seems to have worked OK (?). These will paid for whether with government taxes (deficits) or private fees. How will the carbon tax work with the existing tax structure? Infrastructure spending needs funds. Maybe we don't need new infrastructure, i. e. gridlock forever.

BTW Trump proposes infrastructure spending and without new taxes. Maybe a carbon tax would make sense if he does what he has proposed. I guess those people who like the Trump approach have no problem with deficits!

Comment: "The federal government is responsible for the announcement in airports warning you to report to authorities any stranger who asks you to carry an object aboard an aircraft."

My favorite is the announcements I hear while I'm sitting at the boarding gate telling me that if I left my car parked at the curb out front I'm breaking the rules.  If I went all the way through check-in and security and am ready to board, leaving my car out front, I have bigger problems than a parking ticket.

Comment: I dispute it.  Until you control for all variables, you can't say anything with certainty.  Do you know what gas has the most greenhouse effect? I sneer at government, not scientists.  I think the scientists do what they're paid to do.

Comment: The way airline staff is behaving is nothing new. Many years ago my husband and I were travelling with our then 2 1/2 yr old son. We'd purchased three seats together months prior but due to delayed connecting flights etc. (nothing we did) by the time we arrived in Chicago to catch our final flight it was boarding. There were still three seats left but all separate. When I told the flight attendant I wasn't going to let my 2 1/2 year old son sit beside a stranger on a plane she told me to get off the plane if I didn't like it.  I wasn't asking her to give me the seats we paid for (of course not, that would be well...crazy, right?) but I asked her to make a simple request to passengers seated alone to pair up to make space for me to sit beside my son. She refused while my husband tried to appeal to her non-existant professional side. My son ended up seated on my lap until  the kind gentleman beside me clued into what was going on and changed seats.

Someone could pretty easily walk in with a duffel bag full of guns and  grenades and take out hundreds of people in one fell swoop with the current configuration.

But security is only part of the reason for the reconfiguration.  A design accommodating more automation (kiosks, scanners, etc) should be helpful.  

What I don't buy is the idea that tons of people will be eating and shopping the main hall when it shifts to a security-side space. Once past security, people wanna get to their concourse ASAP. And I don't expect many connecting travelers to go out of their way to the main hall either.

Comment: These four cardinals are quite capable of answering their own "dubia" without attempting to put Pope Francis "on the spot."  Cardinals Burke and Caffara, each of whom has earned the laureate (doctorate) in canon law, could if need be, tutor their fellow cardinals in the concepts of epikeia and courts of chancery, which are and were intended to be a mollification and corrective to the STRICT application of law.  (Courts in the USA generally incorporate the functions of both law and chancery; and family law proceedings, including divorce, are typically allocated to the chancery powers, rather than the law powers, of a court or court system.)  The term "Mercy" is used not infrequently to describe and illustrate the concept and powers of chancery.  These four cardinals ( one JP II appointee and three B XVI appointees!) would have done well to address these matters in their "dubia."  Thus, the papal "non-reply" speaks eloquently on his behalf!

Comment: The GOP bill Trump and McConnell are trying to jam through the Senate will do NOTHING to lower your premiums or deductibles. In fact, it will make them higher.

Maybe you would like to be able to buy a bare bones plan, but those will have even higher deductibles and leave you with huge gaps in coverage, with more hidden exceptions and fewer quality controls. Maybe one plan covers lung cancer but not throat cancer. Or it covers all cancer, but not chemotherapy. 

Or one that covers heart disease but not heart transplants. Another covers statins, but only if you’ve never been diagnosed with heart disease, or maybe just one month’s supply. With so many variables, and so much opportunity for obfuscation, picking the right policy would become impossible because you don't know what your future health problems will be. Consumers might also end up buying “mini-med” insurance that turns out to cover virtually nothing. This happened a lot pre-Obamacare.

Comment: If you are concerned about a service animal, either a dog or a miniature horse, you can legally ask two questions. https://www.ada.gov/service_animals_2010.htm

"The other problem is that the ADA is not the only law in play. For example, the Fair Housing Act and their regulations do allow for emotional support dogs."
http://www.williamgoren.com/blog/2013/04/22/difference-between-service-dogs-and-therapy-dogs/
Note that only trained dogs and some trained miniature horses can legally be Service dogs.
Emotional Support Animals and AAT animals are separate.

Comment: The main reason is that for leadership votes (and all parties use a ranked ballot for their leadership), we are electing an individual, while for general elections, we are electing a representative body. 
The reason this is important is that ranked ballots are bias towards the center because people on the left rank their votes left to right and those on the right rank them right to left, so they end up meeting in the center.  
So when electing an individual, this is good because it prevents candidates from being too extreme, and we are more likely to elect a more consensus candidate, then an extreme one. 
However, when we are electing a parliament, it is supposed to be representative of the support that a party has from the public, and a reflection of the various views that the public hold, if we elect parliament this way then the people who hold views that are too far away from the center will not be reflected in parliament.

Comment: A statistic showing how many workers are currently being paid minimum wage is meaningless. Most businesses that start workers at minimum wage will offer at least small seniority increments, so that somebody who has held the same job for a few years will be earning a dollar or two more than minimum wage. What is needed is the percentage of the labour force whose income is affected by the minimum wage, a multiple of the percentage actually paid minimum wage.

Further, those actually paid minimum wage, being mostly new hires, skew young. Those affected by minimum wage, who average more experienced, will average older and more likely to be dependent on their wages.

Comment: Circumstantial at the moment, but a very powerful correlation.  The average temperature of bodies of water are increasing, warming earlier than in years past.  This provides a longer season for the cyanobacteria to thrive.  Warmer water equals more blooms, longer blooms.  A fraction of a degree of warming can make a big difference.

We need to be at least concerned and cautious about this.  There is a significant, and growing body of evidence that exposure to low-level cyanobacteria toxins are implicated in motor-neuron disease (ALS, Lou Gehrig's Disease).  A lot of communities draw their water from lakes and streams that could be vulnerable to these changes.  I recall Dunes City on the coast having a big problem from a bloom in Siltcoos Lake.  Data suggests that this could be more frequent in the years to come.

.
In First Grade, I lived with my dad... his views about CP were quite the opposite. I went to the principal's office like the 2nd or 3rd day of school. His name was Mr. Hand, I'll never forget his name lol. He told me "If I see you again, I'm gonna spank you with that paddle." I told him the same thing I told the previous principal. The next day I was back down there... he closed the door, grabbed the paddle and made good on his promise. I never went back again.
.
I would support corporeal punishment in schools if it was handled the way it was handled in the early 80's. You just can't argue it's effectiveness.

Comment: Premium fuel is not better than regular fuel for cars that are not setup for it.  Brilliant marketing actually.  Premium fuel is less volatile than regular fuel so that it does not predetonate in high compression engines that run more spark advance for more horsepower. Normal engines will not predetonate due to knock sensors, lower compression, and an engine map that will advance the timing only a certain amount.  The engine map is determined from a number of variables such as compression ratio, valve timing, etc.  Using premium fuel in an engine designed to run on regular is a waste of money as it will not increase performance and may actually reduce gas mileage.  It is not higher quality fuel, it just has different characteristics and costs more money.

Comment: God creates each one of us, but not what we each become. That is called free will, and is necessary for us to be able to choose to love God and follow His ways, or not, and to choose to love our neighbor and treat them well, or not. Comment: "Character slamming someone who claims harassment is beyond inappropriate."

It's actually a significant part of our rules of evidence, in both civil and criminal proceedings.  In a trial, character evidence may be offered to impeach or strengthen the credibility of a witness, subject to certain limitations.

In the context of harassment, sexual assault, etc., you can't introduce character evidence about past sexual conduct (i.e., she slept around so she couldn't have been harassed) - that would certainly be beyond inappropriate, but that is not what is happening here.  You are very much allowed to introduce character evidence that is relevant to evaluating whether a witness is generally honest.

Comment: As with any sales agreement, a "deal" is made when a willing seller and a willing buyer agree on the conditions of a sale.  If a property has "hit" the MLS, they're usually a commission split between the "listing" agent and the "selling" agent.  I agree with some of your statements and disagree with some of them.  

Real estate agents have two tasks: a) convince the seller that the sales price and conditions are to his or her benefit and b) convince the buyer that the sales price and conditions are to his or her's benefit.  If they can't do that, there will be no sale and no commission.  When we've bought properties I've always made it clear that no one is our "buyer's" agent.. we represent ourselves.  If we sell a property, we don't list it exclusively with anyone.  We notify agents and tell them to bring us a "single party" purchase offer and, if the deal works, we'll pay 3%.  This has worked quite well for us.
"Sweetheart Deals" do, unfortunatel,happen and they're very unfair

Comment: Oh, there's one standard all right. It's that our fundamental rights may only be limited in accordance with the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. And to be in accordance, the limitation must first be logically necessary to achieve a PRESSING AND SUBSTANTIVE need. Second, the limitation must be closely connected to the law's objective, violate the right to a reasonable minimum, and be proportional to the intent of the law. If the law fails any one of those test, it's unconstitutional. 

Quebec's law fails at the first test, and likely would fail at the others too.

Comment: You makes it sound like a 401K is a bad thing. If you're working for a company that doesn't invest it well, that's true, but the State of Alaska does a good job of investing the Tier 4 retirement funds and they grow at a good pace. Sure, compared to Tier 1, the Tier 4 worker has to put a lot more of their own money in, but we're legally assured the money will actually be there, whereas the Tier 1 system was never fully funded, so if the State goes bankrupt, Tier 1 retirees may find themselves with no pension.

Defined benefit plans always had this risk, but people weren't aware of it. Defined contribution plans are much more sustainable and, therefore, more likely to be available to the worker at retirement. Your employer can't tap a 401(k). The federal government can ... as they did in Italy and Cyprus to pay down government debt.

Comment: A film about war devoid of the gore is like a film about love devoid of the sex. You can do it, and do it well. But you run the risk of avoiding truth.  And I'm not sure that consciously avoiding truth--so as not to offend-- should be an option.

And as a Vietnam veteran, I also see the sick irony in soldiers who decapitate but don't swear. But more than being ironic, it is being untruthful. Gratuitous violence (like gratuitous nudity, I guess) is wrong. But the "gratuitous elimination" of what is real--agony or euphoria--also is wrong. Very wrong.

War is offensive. And the elimination of reality because "truth offends" is more out of Orwell than out of Hollywood. It is more out of the Legion of Decency than out of history.

It's like when the Legion of Decency (of which Sr. Rose is probably THE expert) used oft-puritanical  standards for decency to arrogantly declare fiction preferable to non fiction. And too often, the truthful message suffered so that the audience wouldn't.

Comment: I've jumped a number of stranger's cars over the years who've waved jumper cables at me in a parking lot.  I always pull up alongside them, roll down my window, and then with my meanest face and deepest menacing voice, I say "Hey Buddy, you trying to start something?".  Always gets a laugh after a few seconds.  I carry a very long, very heavy duty set of booster cables in my truck.  I never use the pieces of junk that people buy from CTire.  I also have a connector under my hood that I use to connect my removable winch and I connect the booster cables to the connector.  First connect the Red (+) on the connector or battery to the Red (+) post on the dead vehicle's battery unless they have a separate red lug for boosting.  Then connect the charging Black (-) to a solid ground point on the dead car or if you can't find one, connect to the negative or Black post.  By connecting the Black (-) last to a separate ground point greatly reduces the danger of explosion in the event of a spark.

Comment: Your argument is the fallacy of false dichotomy. We know nothing unless we have data. Let's break this down.
First, what is your criteria for valid data? Traffic? Accidents? If we have valid data, what numbers represent success/failure? Is a 10% increase in traffic along side streets a failure? 
By "data" I assume you mean numbers. What of evidence from users? We know the neighborhood association has deemed it a favorable outcome. Is this an indicator of success? If we found side streets through this neighborhood had increased traffic and yet the association said they are in favor of the project, is that not success?
Shall we dismiss other sources of data? Some business owners have come to favor the project. Probably some don't. Very few allowed the city to look at financials. What do we make of these facts?
I think we can make some assumptions about the success without your claim that we need certain data to know anything. I will state the successes are greater than before.

Comment: It's equal pay for EQUAL WORK.  

Whether it's the average earnings comparison in this study, or the average wage comparison done in this study, they have not controlled for equality in the position, so their conclusions are virtually useless in determining if discrimination has occurred. These studies tell us volumes about different priorities, work habits, family choices, etc. but implying we have widespread discriminatory practice, worthy of an "outrageous" from a working prof in Canada? How dishonest!.

The  Korn Ferry Hay Group did a study that went well past most governmental studies, right to the same employer and same job title, and was one of the first studies to do so.  They found that in their 33 nation sample, with 8.7M subjects, the average gap in those 33 western nations (Canada included), was a tiny 1.6%.  When simply controlling for employer and position makes the gap vanish? It's not an issue.

http://info.haygroupupdate.com/global-en-gender-pay-gap-white-paper.html

Comment: I'll have to support the above post.  I worked in a 92-bed locked psychiatric facility from 1980 through 1988.  For all but one year I worked graveyard shift, and it was my and one or two other staff members' responsibility to quickly respond to the alarm indicating an out-of-control violent individual was in the 'screening' area.  If it was a drunk, the duty LVN would meet us in the hallway on our way there and so inform us.  This was important, because we knew better than to try to talk a drunk out of being violent.  Therefore we entered the screening area, quickly assessed the situation for any unusual hazards, then without a word immediately piled on the drunk and applied restraints.  I've carefully talked PCP-intoxicated individuals into accompanying me and a colleague into a 'seclusion' room, lie down and cooperate while we quickly applied restraints.  I'd never have tried that with a drunk.  There's simply no talking to 'em.  Immobilize 'em and wait for 'em to sober up.

Comment: "Do you realize that active volcanos produce more CO2 than most countries combined", perhaps, if they are all small countries like Luxemburg or highly enlightened countries such as Germany, Iceland and Sweden who produce very little CO2, due to their advanced state of efficiency and high levels of renewable energy production. Comment: The Alaska Division of Geological & Geophysical Surveys has many recent, free, downloadable reports and maps showing the results of tsunami inundation modeling for southern coastal communities. Just go to dggs.alaska.gov, click on Publications Search, and enter "tsunami inundation" as a keyword. The maps show areas of maximum inundation based on UAF computer modeling of multiple known and potential earthquake and submarine landslide sources.

Comment: Incorrect?
1.  Per capital data is irrelevant when populations vary so much, that's why real economists don't use it.  BTW, Alberta per capita spending is 5th to 7th out of 10 provinces in data, not last.
2. Revenue per capital is lower in Alta than BC and Ontario by 2016.  Last revenue per capital data on Stats Can is for 2014, before oil price collapse.  See special revenue for Alberta in 2014, that disappears by 2016.  Also, Ontario is supported by federal per capita revenue which is 50% more than any province.  Finally, Stats Canada data does not include PST, Alta has no PST.
3. Being slightly younger province and the highest growing population province for many years means Alberta has a far greater infrastructure need (schools, roads, education for all students from kindergarten through technical college and university, and health care for young families is also expensive).
4.  Most of your key statistics are heresay, not really any definitive proof or definitive way to measure

Comment: The Eisenhower Commission, tasked with studying the causes of violence in American life and recommending policies, proposed a ban on private ownership of handguns, except where particular need existed.  It didn't suggest a buyback program but outright confiscation.  But, of course, the commission  were assuming that the country actually placed a high priority on curbing gun violence.  We now know that was never true, and is even further from the truth today than it was in 1969.  

I've mentioned before that seeing guns, including automatic weapons, carried openly is common in Israel.  Yet, apart from terrorist attacks (most of which in recent years have been with knives), gun crimes are rare.  One reason is that it's illegal to own a private handgun in Israel without obtaining a permit that requires one to demonstrate need, proficiency and safety.  Simple common sense, no?  Alas, totally out of American reach.  The slaughter--I include all gun victims--stretches unbroken before us.

Comment: Seriously? Employees who need their own space are "resistors"? I get she's basically advertising her business, but this kind of shortsighted insult is not productive. Obviously the kind of job you have dictates what kind of space you need. Not all jobs are "collaborative" (mine certainly isn't) or can be done "sitting on an open floor with colleagues." "Resistance to change" is a well-known management meme and code for "if it's not working it's your fault," a rather Freudian approach to employee management. I thought this worn claptrap had gone the way of the dodo. Yes, there may be elements of that in any organization, and some jobs, especially in IT where there is a team approach to certain types of tasks, do benefit from open spaces and in-your-face interaction, but this is by no means generalizable. This article is a poorly-thought-out piece of marketing IMHO.

Comment: Agreed. 

When considering places to live, the per capita rate of gun deaths is one useful measure of personal risk.  In the U.S. it is about 10.54 gun deaths per 100,000 people (2014 count). In the U.K. it is about 0.23 per 100,000, or 46X lower; in India it is 37X lower, Japan 175X lower, Australia 11X lower.

Of course in some places, like El Salvador and Guatemala, this risk is much higher.

Stephen J. Remington

Comment: Some years ago I dislocated my elbow and was given a pretty hefty prescription to Percocet. I had a big bottle, a month's worth.

Man it worked. I was able to get to sleep nightly and have a good night's sleep, with kinda cool dreams.

As I was nearing the end of my prescription, I really liked the dreams, so I started to think of how I might go about acquiring some Percocet illegally. This went on for a couple of nights. I lived in Denver at the time and I figured I could go down to Colfax and Logan and meet someone who would set me right up.

My prescription finally got low, down to less than half a dozen. You know what I did? I stopped taking the Percocet, because I'm NOT A FREAKING JUNKIE!

This idea that the drug companies cause addiction is ludicrous. What causes addiction is junkies deciding they'd rather be high than contribute.

Comment: Chip Fletcher says we need public service announcements warning about global warming.  But why?  If global warming is actually happening and inevitable, then there's nothing we can do about it.  Mr. Fletcher's demand for PSAs on global warming is like Henny Penny pushing PSAs to warn that the sky is falling, or some fringe religious groups demanding PSAs that "the end [of the world] is near" and "Jesus is coming."  

A PSA is not "sponsored" -- it's paid for as a donation of on-air time by a broadcaster, in the public interest, perhaps to satisfy a requirement imposed by the FCC that a broadcast license requires some on-air time be devoted to public forums and announcements "pro bono" (free and for the benefit of the public).  The purpose of a PSA is to inform the public about something important that people are not yet aware of.  For example:  "Time to get your flu shot."  PSAs should not be used for political propaganda.

Comment: If the buildings without sprinklers really are putting their occupants at risk, then units in those buildings are worth less than otherwise comparable buildings with sprinklers.  I suspect that they are not assessed at less.  If that is so, then the city council should take the difference in tax between what owners of units without sprinklers pay, and what they would pay if the difference in value was incorporated in the assessment, and put that money into a special fund that those condo associations can draw on to upgrade the safety of their buildings.  If buildings without sprinklers are in fact assessed at less than comparable buildings with sprinklers, the City Council should gross them up to the assessment they would have if they had sprinklers and put that money in a fund the building associations could draw on.  Either way, the buildings would have a strong incentive to submit plans to install sprinklers or otherwise make the buildings safer to get their money back.

Comment: I've always accepted the advice to get inoculated against the flu each year. However, it's very disconcerting to learn that last year the vaccine was only 35-40% effective against the H3N2 strain, especially when it was considered at the time to be a very good match to the virus that was circulating in Canada. In my own case, I came down very hard with the flu, despite getting the shot. 

Given my experience from last year, and that this year's vaccine is very likely to be useless against H3N2, I'm not convinced that it's worthwhile getting vaccinated this year.

Comment: Debate about gun laws spikes after mass shootings because their carnage reminds us that guns are uniquely and efficiently deadly, and pitifully under-regulated relative to the risks they pose. Yet gun violence in the United States is also unacceptably mundane, taking one or two lives at a time, all the time, with little fanfare and few headlines — just an ambulance carrying away the corpse of another battered wife, another child, another mentally ill person who felt she had no other option. Some of these deaths would happen even if the nation had sensible gun laws. Many would not. 

The research that exists increasingly shows there are effective measures that reduce gun deaths without materially infringing on law-abiding people’s liberty: deny firearms to domestic abusers, for example; perform serious background checks on would-be gun buyers; require that gun owners obtain a license. Such measures...would make society safer. 

—So, About That ‘Good Guy’ With A Gun 
Washington Post 7/12

Comment: Clearly the major internet tourism exposure that Mermaid Caves/Tunnels is getting is going to lead to some tragic deaths/drownings, if it hasn't already. 
.
These beautiful ancient coral reef karst caves are an example of hundreds more found in more remote locations around Oahu and Kauai. There used to be many in Pearl Harbor used by sharks. Formed by fresh water flowing through the limestone dissolving into caves and water channels, they are an example of how mountain streams, which now largely flow below the ground, reach the ocean.
.
Unfortunately because these caves are very accessible and right at a dangerous changing sea level subject to tides and wave action is going to lead to tourist deaths. They will be an ever growing tourism magnet for those who literally don't understand what they are getting into.
.
Unfortunately everything now is up for sale and fast cash exploitation pushed by tourism agencies with no responsibilities. Leeward residents can expect tons more coming.

Comment: "Stories that have been retold for 400 years like Romeo and Julie...are valuable because they permeate popular culture. Not reading them is a disservice, because understanding pop-culture references and their original sources is valuable cultural capital. It can help newcomers with belonging and social mobility. It bridges gaps between cultures and generations. It reveals similarities rather than merely emphasizing differences."

Shared cultural references are what hold a society together.

Comment: After 65 years in Alaska, I never take the beauty for granted. I love sharing the beauty with visitors, which I just spent three weeks doing. Visiting places I've been countless times; I never tire of having my breath taken away with the views both large and small. Even right here in Anchorage, with five mountain ranges around us, the quality of the light in all its mutations throughout the seasons, and the changes in weather fills me with awe daily. Recently standing at the end of Turnagain Arm and thinking of the hundreds of time I had taken in that view, I was moved to tears at the natural beauty that is my home. Sitting at a red light, almost anywhere in Anchorage, I see people looking completely oblivious to their surroundings. All you have to do is look up-look at the mountains, the clouds, the view!  I know all of the places that the roads rise up and give you a far off view of the Alaska Range, the Aleutians, the Talkeetnas; and of course, the ever present Chugach. Never dull.

Comment: "I respect your knowledge and wisdom."

That's a mistake, as I am sure many readers will agree.

"Please tell me why this egregious hatred of the poor is happening...?"

I do not agree that Canadians hate the poor. 

What I mean is that I think that Canadians see the poor as diverse. 

But I think there is a segment of the poor that many Canadians have very little patience for. And those are the poor who are able, in body and mind, to work at a job, but who instead choose to spend huge tracts of time on welfare. You should ask yourself: Are there people in Canada gaming the welfare system which gives them (gaming people) too much and too easily? Of course there are. Not to go too "tin foil" but it is intellectually inconsistent (and more than a bit hypocritical) to worry about any given administration, like the current one, being an extrajudicial threat to the civil rights of their opponents, then hand them the power to arbitrarily declare people "insane," without legal recourse, and incarcerate them just because you have a problem with one single such right.

Again not going Godwin nor Stalin-ing, but we have real, fairly recent experience with that sort of thing. If people truly fear the current admin they can't logically make this one case an exception.

Comment: Missing from this assessment of 'leadership', and in any discussion of 'great leaders' as icons is any mention of acceptance of consequences - in another word, INTEGRITY. The icons mentioned became icons, because the consequences of their actions worked out in their favour. 

Not mentioned, however are the leaders for whom the results of their actions did not lead to fame, fortune or personal success, but whose leadership was no less heroic, and no less worthy of replication, in fact, perhaps more so. 

My grandfather was also a war hero; there's a line in the citation for his medal that tells me all I need to know about leadership, and my aspiration to it: "encircled by the enemy, he was given the chance to evacuate by sea. Instead, he chose to fight is way out, with his men".  My grandfather died shortly after the war, I never knew him. There are no schools, no streets, no airports named for him. 

That doesn't make him any less of a leader.

Comment: Industrial hemp is an interesting construction material. From what little I have read about it appears to be an insulation material to be used along side tradition metal or wood framing (not like lego building blocks). 

Industrial hemp would grow well in Hawaii but according to this website:

http://bringingithomemovie.com/hemp-house-top-10

2.5 acres (109,000 sf.) of land yields just enough hemp to be used in one 1,250 sf. house. Keep in mind that you would still need wood for the framing and roof. Also in order for the hemp to be made into the "hempcrete" lime binder is needed which can come from limestone deposits or coral. 

I found this article here,

http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2002/Feb/19/ln/ln22a.html

that talks about a lime stone deposit in Kauai. I don't think Hawaii is keen on mining or grinding up coral. Also the state owns all mineral rights to the land anyway and mining can only be done by leasing the mineral rights. Hemp construction is expensive.

Comment: Quite frankly, until you start doing algebra and then calculus, which generally starts at around grade 7 or so, what kids are doing in elementary school is the most basic arithmetic. Adding, subtracting, learning about multiplication and division (more advanced obviously) and finally, doing these things with fractions. 

As others have pointed out on this board, pretty well all of us who've gone through the Canadian school system have learned this stuff.  Some few people (and it is a minority still) may have learning disabilities that make it difficult for them to grasp the abstraction of numbers.  But most of us don't . I'm not a teacher and have showed kids how to do these basic things.

So I agree with this author - the new curriculum is uselessly challenging both the kids and their teachers.   I would suggest that this be dropped,  and that students with special needs have special instruction, and the rest just do their numbers. And learn not to be scared of basic arithmetic.

Comment: Part 1 or 2

Whether one agrees with Brexit or not, it cannot be denied that the delivery of this divorce note represents the popular will of Britons as determined by a free and fair referendum. May should be commended for executing the decision of British voters, although it could be argued that the nine month delay in initiating Brexit negotiations was excessively long, creating a needless period of uncertainty and anxiety that has only now been brought to an end.

The contention presented in this article that the EU "cannot afford to give London generous terms that might encourage other member states to break away" is arguable, and suggests many people have still not taken the lessons of Brexit to heart. In fact, it was the domineering, my-way-or-the-highway style of the EU bureaucracy and political class that in many ways drove Britons to seek greater national autonomy. Spitefully seeking to punish Britain during the Brexit discussions would only highlight this negative trait.

Comment: Most teachers already have their classrooms open at lunch, not that lunch is long enough for most extracurriculars. And where does the money come from for expanded subsidized child care? You're right that school is about student learning. But part of that learning is also preparing them for life, to be a productive member of society. To be able to function in a workplace, and the reality is that your typical supervisor sent going to care if you're tired or don't want to get up as early. You could argue that it's a temporary need during adolescence, but there are young people who work right out of graduating high school, over the summer, on weekends, etc.

It's an opportunity to teach perseverance and resiliency, and that sometimes things aren't going to be given to you or that sacrifice is required to get ahead.

Comment: "This article just sounds like someone who did not get his way on November 8, 2016. Your reprehensible candidate lost to the other reprehensible candidate. Get over it".

 You are correct in that this article, while impassioned, does not lay out a legal argument for impeachment. 

However, you might consider that its no longer about the elections results, but rather what has been learned since the election. A special counsel has been named and a grand jury has been empaneled. That loud noise resembling a freight train (some might call it strategic leaking) is the sound of federal indictments coming down. Indictments lead to proffers and "substantial cooperation" which leads to bigger, more important indictments. This is precisely how our federal judicial system is designed to operate.  Do not be fooled by the pace of the investigation. This is not a liquor store hold up and we are not watching CSI. Repeating "get over it" may be comforting now, but this case is a long way from over.

Comment: Renewables (PV and wind) will only really be cheaper, once the energy-storage problem is solved.  For the most obvious option, that needs battery prices to drop by between one and two orders of magnitude. (ie between 10 and 100-fold).  
The proposals for gas-turbine powered backup generation for renewable failure times sounds technically attractive, but so far the costs have not been examined thoroughly.  These include capital redemption (capital, plus interest payments), maintenance costs and fuel costs.  For fuel, locally-produced gas supplies remain in the realm of speculation, whilst imported supplies would leave us at the mercies of the international oil traders.  Looking at the history of oil-product prices over the last half-century the latter does not leave me with a happy feeling.
The German "Energiewende" experience has been, to put it tactfully, equivocal.

Comment: I'm saying this story offers one narrative about a specific case. We don't hear from the TA or the administrator who issued the suspension. Emergency suspensions don't happen in a vacuum, and certainly aren't stuck to in the midst of an appeal if they are baseless. My experience tells me that there is likely much more to this story.

I never said IDEA should entirely be written off. I said it gets abused, and is an example of federal overreach and underfunded mandates. That doesn't mean we shouldn't educate students with disabilities. I do think the manifestation determination process is arbitrarily set at ten days and can provide students to engage in all sorts of behavior if you slap a label of disability on something, but then not moved to a more restrictive environment. That can adversely effect the learning environment for every other student, and they need someone looking at for their rights, too.

You're comparing apples to oranges. A system/legal framework isn't the same.

Comment: Like it or not, labor is the basis of profit--defined herein as the difference between the labor the factory owner pays for and the labor he gets.  Why else do you imagine it's more PROFITABLE to send frozen salmon, cod and pollock fillets and H&G from Alaska to the People's Republic of China for further processing, then ship 'em back here to be sold as finished products than it is to process finished seafood products here?  Because Chinese workers get paid pittances, and American workers won't--indeed in most cases CAN'T--work for wages that low. Comment: I never liked budget caps.  They just always make bad sense to me and usually end up as a tool for political ploys.  A legislature requires the executive to cover so many obligations, often without bothering to conduct a reasonable study of how much those things costs.  Even when when they do have the studies the costs get adjusted the following year/session especially if there is a change in majority.  AND there is never enough money to cover all of them so each chamber, let alone each majority, have their own spending priorities.
Legislatures cannot accept responsibility for creating and not properly maintaining a budget cap and because the fault is distributed over a number of representatives constituents rarely if ever recognize who is really at fault when there is a budget deficit.  So the executive gets left holding the bag.
This isn't to say that the executive may not be contributorily or even wholly responsible, like for example buying a jet despite the legislature.

At Vatican II, there was a very different 'play-book'' used. Comment: Just a few years ago, in 2008, Anchorage voters overwhelmingly rejected a similar plan (65% against).  What is different now?

The reasons given for these "open up the taxicab industry" regulations don't make sense and the plan won't work.  Taxi companies aren't going to service areas where they can't make as much money as they want, no matter how many permits are added.  The problems are with providing services to these areas that cab companies don't want.  No additional permits, no Uber or Lyft will solve those problems.  Add more cab companies, or Uber/Lyft, and all you will get is every company trying to cherry pick the good areas until some go out of business and there is much less service for everyone.  It happens over and over again.  That's why there is a limited entry cab system now.

Comment: Actually, affordability can be achieved in Vancouver, but no politician has yet stepped forward to embrace the obvious method - which is to apply PROPERTY tax rates on houses that would reflect the annual INCOME TAX needed to explain an ability to buy such a house.

In other words, if you are the doctor and lawyer couple working in Vancouver and earning together 600,000 per year, and your income tax to Ottawa and Victoria is 220,000 per year, fine, your house property tax is set at 12,000 a year. 

However if you are the 21 year old student who mysteriously owns a three million dollar house in Vancouver and neither you nor the family member who "gave" you the house has at lest a ten year working history in Canada with substantial income taxes paid to Ottawa, then YOUR property tax rate is 220,000 per year, matching the tax levels of the local working family's income taxes needed to live there.

Implement that system and house prices in Vancouver drop by half within five years.
